Situation1: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: The child's bar mitzvah is approaching, and they have not yet mastered the Torah portion.
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, white coat draped over my chair, a pharmacy newsletter open on my phone. New drug approvals, updated guidelines—my mind raced to keep up. I knew I had to stay sharp, for my patients and my license. But as I scrolled, my phone buzzed with a message from my spouse: “He’s struggling with his Torah portion. Can you help tonight?” My son’s bar mitzvah was only weeks away, and he still stumbled over the Hebrew, his confidence wavering. I was supposed to guide him, to pass on our traditions, to make sure he felt proud and prepared. Yet every evening, I found myself buried in medical journals or answering after-hours calls from the pharmacy. The weight of both worlds pressed on me—my duty to my patients, my responsibility to my family and faith. I stared at the newsletter, then at the message, feeling the familiar ache of being pulled in two directions, unsure which role needed me more in this moment.
